TITLE:  CCU INTERN PROGRESS NOTE
   Chief Complaint:  Intubated s/p cardiac arrest
   24 Hour Events:
   Patient did well overnight, kept on maintenance IVF at 75ml/hr.  Also
   febrile to 100.6, not on any antibiotics at this time.
   Some runs of non-sustained Vtach overnight.
   Allergies:
   Penicillins
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Ranitidine (Prophylaxis) - [**2159-6-25**] 11:38 PM

   PaO2 / FiO2: 271
   Physical Examination
   GENERAL - sedated, comfortable male on a ventilator
   HEENT - pupils slightly reactive, sclerae anicteric, MMM, Conjunctiva
   were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
   NECK - supple, no thyromegaly, no apparent JVD but difficult to assess
   b/c patient on neck brace, no carotid bruits
   LUNGS
 coarse breath sounds throughout the lungs, on ventilator
   HEART - PMI located in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. RRR,
   normal S1, S2. Systolic murmur II/VI near apex. No thrills, lifts. No
   S3 or S4.
   ABDOMEN - NABS, soft/NT/ND, no masses or HSM, no rebound/guarding. Abd
   aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.
   EXTREMITIES - WWP, no c/c/e, 2+ peripheral pulses (radials, DPs), No
   c/c/e. No femoral bruits.
   SKIN - no rashes or lesions. Slight skin breakdown behind neck where
   collar was rubbing.  Slight burn marks where defibrillator pads were on
   abdomen.
   LYMPH - no cervical, axillary, or inguinal LAD
   NEURO - responding to pain, not following commands, sedated.
   PULSES:
   Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
   Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
   Labs / Radiology

   WBC

   Hct

   226

   26
   Glucose
   124
   135
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:12.4/23.3/1.0, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:[**2070-5-6**]/0.04 (decreased from 2909/6/0.04), ALT / AST:109/89
   (decreased from 129/116), Alk Phos / T Bili:69/1.8, Amylase /
   Lipase:/19, Differential-Neuts:90.2 %, Lymph:6.0 %, Mono:3.1 %, Eos:0.6
   %, Albumin:3.3 g/dL, LDH:506 IU/L, Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.4 mg/dL,
   PO4:1.9 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname 7331**] is a 64 YO M wtih history of MVP and bicuspid aortic
   valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation
   in cardiac enzymes and LFTs transfered for further work up.
   .
   #. Cardiac arrest - Unclear etiology, but patient was having
   wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The preciptiant of the cardiac
   arrest is still unclear and etiologies suggest arrhythmia (VFib
   specificallY) or seizure. Stroke with AFib is another posibility, but
   we cannot assess any deficits a this time given sedation.  Also
   possible it could be ischemia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Serial ECGs
   - Trend CE
   - Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1795**]: cardiac cath today to r/o CAD
   - Neurology consult today re: ?seizure and mental status off sedation
   -> cortical function given minimally responsive state
   .
   #. CAD - Patient with normal stress test 2 weeks prior, multiple ECG
   changes (right and left bunndle as above), Trop I of 2.24 and CK of
   ~5500 with negative MBI. He does not have any risk factors, was not on
   aspirin and did not have chest pain. This makes unlikley that he has
   CAD as presenting symptom.
   - Cardiac cath today
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Trend CE
   - Serial ECGs
   - Continue Metorpolol (increased to 50mg po/ng TID)
   - On simvastatin 20mg po daily
   - No indications for ACEI/[**Last Name (un) 284**] given not known CAD and most-likley
   increased CE after CPR
   - ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Plavix load given
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt currently with LBBB morphology, but RBBB in multiple
   ECGs at other hospital. Pt also has extensive ectopy. At this time his
   electrolytes are normal. No signs of ischemia. Dilated heart in
   echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF, bicuspid AS and mixomatous
   degeneration of mitral valve. [**Month (only) 11**] be going in and out of Atrial
   Fibrilation.
   - Repelte electrolytes PRN
   - Continue metoprolol 50 mg TID for now
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   - EP consult in AM
   - Discuss anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH. Will
   hold until CT scan negative.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of heart failure at this time. Preserved EF.
   .
   #. Fever - Pt was found down and s/p cooling protocol. WBC was high up
   to 14,000. No signs of infection on CXR and UA clean at OSH. Concern
   for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. Given no infiltrates
   will hold on antibiotics for now. Withdrawal is another consideration.
   Febrile to 100.6 last night.
   - FU U/A
   - FU CXR
   - FU Blood cultures
   - No antibiotics for now
   .
   #. Alcohol abuse - Pt with last drink 4 days ago. Has been getting
   ativan and valium. No signs of withdrawal at this time (HR, BP
   adequte), but difficult to assess given beta-blocker and sedated.
   - CIWA with ativan given shock liver; will hold for now pending neuro
   consult
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 7334**] LFTs - Pt with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the
   settinf of code and being found down.
   - Trend LFTs
   - BP management as above
   .
   #. Hematuria - Resolved. Most likely traumatic after Foley placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding feeds until extubation, no diet for 3 days so far
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines: 18 Gauge - [**2159-6-25**] 08:00 PM (PIV x 3 from OSH)
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SC heparin
   Stress ulcer: Ranitidine per NGT
   Bowel regimen: Colace/senna
   VAP:  HOB 30 degrees, mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Wife [**Name (NI) 288**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Known lastname 7331**]s Home [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7335**] & Cell
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7336**]
   Code status: Full code (confirmed with wife)
   Disposition:  CCU for now, cath today

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who was found down and intubated after a cardiac arrest. The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, suggesting possible ischemia or cardiac injury.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure of 127/69 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is febrile, with a temperature of 100.6°F, and has a white blood cell count of 11.3 x 10^9/L.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is of unclear etiology, but possible causes include arrhythmia, seizure, or stroke.
2. CAD: The patient has a history of normal stress test, but multiple ECG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes suggest possible CAD.
3. Rhythm: The patient has a complex rhythm, with LBBB morphology and extensive ectopy.
4. Fever: The patient's fever is of unclear etiology, but possible causes include aspiration pneumonia, aspiration pneumonitis, or withdrawal.
5. LFTs: The patient's LFTs are elevated, suggesting possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.
6. Hematuria: The patient has resolved hematuria, which was likely traumatic after Foley placement.

The patient's medications include:

1. Ranitidine (prophylaxis)
2. Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
3. Metoprolol (50 mg TID)
4. Simvastatin (20 mg daily)
5. ASA (325 mg daily)
6. Plavix (75 mg daily)

The patient's plan includes:

1. Cardiac catheterization to rule out CAD
2. Serial ECGs and telemetry monitoring
3. Trending of cardiac enzymes and LFTs
4. Neurology consult to assess possible seizure or stroke
5. EP consult to discuss anticoagulation for AFib
6. CT scan to rule out stroke or other intracranial pathology
7. Monitoring for signs of heart failure or pump failure
8. Fever management, including FU U/A, CXR, and blood cultures
9. LFT monitoring and management
10. Hematuria monitoring and management.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   arrest is still unclear and etiologies suggest arrhythmia (VFib
   specificallY) or seizure. Stroke with AFib is another posibility, but
   we cannot assess any deficits a this time given sedation.  Also
   possible it could be ischemia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Serial ECGs
   - Trend CE
   - Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1795**]: cardiac cath today to r/o CAD
   - Neurology consult today re: ?seizure
   .
   #. CAD - Patient with normal stress test 2 weeks prior, multiple ECG
   changes (right and left bunndle as above), Trop I of 2.24 and CK of
   ~5500 with negative MBI. He does not have any risk factors, was not on
   aspirin and did not have chest pain. This makes unlikley that he has
   CAD as presenting symptom.
   - Cardiac cath today
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Trend CE
   - Serial ECGs
   - Continue Metorpolol (increased to 50mg po/ng TID)
   - On simvastatin 20mg po daily
   - No indications for ACEI/[**Last Name (un) 284**] given not known CAD and most-likley
   increased CE after CPR
   - ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Plavix load given
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt currently with LBBB morphology, but RBBB in multiple
   ECGs at other hospital. Pt also has extensive ectopy. At this time his
   electrolytes are normal. No signs of ischemia. Dilated heart in
   echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF, bicuspid AS and mixomatous
   degeneration of mitral valve. [**Month (only) 11**] be going in and out of Atrial
   Fibrilation.
   - Repelte electrolytes PRN
   - Continue metoprolol 50 mg TID for now
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   - Echcoardiogram in AM to assess for WMA
   - EP consult in AM
   - Discuss anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH. Will
   hold until CT scan negative.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of heart failure at this time. Preserved EF.
   .
   #. Fever - Pt was found down and s/p cooling protocol. WBC was high up
   to 14,000. No signs of infection on CXR and UA clean at OSH. Concern
   for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. Given no infiltrates
   will hold on antibiotics for now. Withdrawal is another consideration.
   Febrile to 100.6 last night.
   - FU U/A
   - FU CXR
   - FU Blood cultures
   - No antibiotics for now
   .
   #. Alcohol abuse - Pt with last drink 4 days ago. Has been getting
   ativan and valium. No signs of withdrawal at this time (HR, BP
   adequte), but difficult to assess given beta-blocker and sedated.
   - CIWA with ativan given shock liver
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 7334**] LFTs - Pt with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the
   settinf of code and being found down.
   - Trend LFTs
   - BP management as above
   .
   #. Hematuria - Resolved. Most likely traumatic after Foley placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding feeds until extubation, no diet for 3 days so far
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines: 18 Gauge - [**2159-6-25**] 08:00 PM (PIV x 3 from OSH)
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SC heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   Bowel regimen: Colace/senna
   VAP:  Ranitidine per NGT and 30 degrees, mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Wife [**Name (NI) 288**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Known lastname 7331**]s Home [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7335**] & Cell
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7336**]
   Code status: Full code (confirmed with wife)
   Disposition:  CCU for now, cath today

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest. He was found down and had a wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The etiology of the cardiac arrest is unclear, but possible causes include arrhythmia, seizure, stroke, and ischemia. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has a fever of 100.6°F. He has a history of alcohol abuse and is currently being treated for possible aspiration pneumonia versus aspiration pneumonitis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 100.6°F, HR 85 bpm, BP 127/69 mmHg, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure 12 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure 35/20 mmHg, cardiac output 4.5 L/min
* Fluid balance: 156 mL of fluid has been given over the past 24 hours, with a total fluid balance of 477 mL
* Respiratory support: Mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min, and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O
* Laboratory results: White blood cell count 11.3 K/uL, hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL, creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, and troponin T 0.04 ng/mL

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and wide-complex tachycardia suggest that he may be at risk for future cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's fever and possible aspiration pneumonia versus aspiration pneumonitis make pneumonia a potential complication.
3. Sepsis: The patient's high white blood cell count and possible infection make sepsis a potential complication.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's history of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the setting of code and being found down make liver dysfunction a potential complication.
5. Neurological deficits: The patient's sedation and possible seizure or stroke make neurological deficits a potential complication.
6. Acute kidney injury: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and possible hypotension make acute kidney injury a potential complication.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and possible deep venous thrombosis make pulmonary embolism a potential complication.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and possible stress ulcer make gastrointestinal bleeding a potential complication.

   Mr. [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname 7331**] is a 64 YO M wtih history of MVP and bicuspid aortic
   valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation
   in cardiac enzymes and LFTs transfered for further work up.
   .
   #. Cardiac arrest - Unclear etiology, but patient was having
   wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The preciptiant of the cardiac
   arrest is still unclear and etiologies suggest arrhythmia (VFib
   specificallY) or seizure. Stroke with AFib is another posibility, but
   we cannot assess any deficits a this time given sedation.  Also
   possible it could be ischemia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Serial ECGs
   - Trend CE
   - Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1795**]: cardiac cath today to r/o CAD
   - Neurology consult today re: ?seizure
   .
   #. CAD - Patient with normal stress test 2 weeks prior, multiple ECG
   changes (right and left bunndle as above), Trop I of 2.24 and CK of
   ~5500 with negative MBI. He does not have any risk factors, was not on
   aspirin and did not have chest pain. This makes unlikley that he has
   CAD as presenting symptom.
   - Cardiac cath today
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Trend CE
   - Serial ECGs
   - Continue Metorpolol (increased to 50mg po/ng TID)
   - On simvastatin 20mg po daily
   - No indications for ACEI/[**Last Name (un) 284**] given not known CAD and most-likley
   increased CE after CPR
   - ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Plavix load given
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   .
   #. Rhythm - Pt currently with LBBB morphology, but RBBB in multiple
   ECGs at other hospital. Pt also has extensive ectopy. At this time his
   electrolytes are normal. No signs of ischemia. Dilated heart in
   echocardiogram in pt with preserved EF, bicuspid AS and mixomatous
   degeneration of mitral valve. [**Month (only) 11**] be going in and out of Atrial
   Fibrilation.
   - Repelte electrolytes PRN
   - Continue metoprolol 50 mg TID for now
   - Serial ECGs
   - Telemetry
   - Echcoardiogram in AM to assess for WMA
   - EP consult in AM
   - Discuss anticoagulation for AFib, poor candidate given EtOH. Will
   hold until CT scan negative.
   .
   #. Pump - No signs of heart failure at this time. Preserved EF.
   .
   #. Fever - Pt was found down and s/p cooling protocol. WBC was high up
   to 14,000. No signs of infection on CXR and UA clean at OSH. Concern
   for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. Given no infiltrates
   will hold on antibiotics for now. Withdrawal is another consideration.
   Febrile to 100.6 last night.
   - FU U/A
   - FU CXR
   - FU Blood cultures
   - No antibiotics for now
   .
   #. Alcohol abuse - Pt with last drink 4 days ago. Has been getting
   ativan and valium. No signs of withdrawal at this time (HR, BP
   adequte), but difficult to assess given beta-blocker and sedated.
   - CIWA with ativan given shock liver
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 7334**] LFTs - Pt with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis in the
   settinf of code and being found down.
   - Trend LFTs
   - BP management as above
   .
   #. Hematuria - Resolved. Most likely traumatic after Foley placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding feeds until extubation, no diet for 3 days so far

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest with unclear etiology. He has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve. The patient was found to have wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM, and the precipitant of the cardiac arrest is still unclear. He has been diagnosed with LBBB morphology, and his electrolytes are normal. He has a preserved EF and no signs of heart failure. He is febrile to 100.6, and his WBC is high at 11.3. He has no signs of infection on CXR and UA, and he is being monitored for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis. He has a history of alcohol abuse and is being monitored for signs of withdrawal.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's high WBC count and fever suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's febrile episode and high WBC count could be indicative of aspiration pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure and death.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and LBBB morphology suggest the possibility of cardiac complications, such as ventricular fibrillation or cardiac tamponade, which could lead to cardiac arrest and death.
4. Withdrawal Syndrome: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and current sedation could lead to withdrawal syndrome, which could result in seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and death.
5. Ischemic Hepatitis: The patient's LFTs are elevated, suggesting the possibility of ischemic hepatitis, which could lead to liver failure and death.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is on a ventilator. He may be at risk for respiratory failure, which could lead to death.
7. Hemorrhagic Shock: The patient's high WBC count and fever could lead to hemorrhagic shock, which could result in organ dysfunction and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and WBC count, and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Consider antibiotics for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis.
5. Consider treatment for withdrawal syndrome if the patient shows signs of withdrawal.
6. Monitor the patient's LFTs and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Consider treatment for ischemic hepatitis if the patient's LFTs continue to be elevated.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust treatment accordingly.

Summary:

The patient, a 64-year-old male, was admitted to the ICU after experiencing cardiac arrest and subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and liver function tests. He has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve and was found down with wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM. The patient is currently intubated and on a ventilator, with a heart rate of 85 BPM and blood pressure of 127/69 mmHg. He is febrile to 100.6°F and has a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL. The patient's electrolytes are normal, and he has no signs of ischemia. He is being monitored on telemetry and is scheduled for a cardiac catheterization today to rule out CAD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is unclear, and potential etiologies include arrhythmia, seizure, or stroke. He is at risk for further cardiac events.
2. CAD: The patient has a history of normal stress test 2 weeks prior, but with multiple ECG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes, CAD is a possibility. He is scheduled for a cardiac catheterization today to rule out CAD.
3. Rhythm disturbances: The patient has LBBB morphology on ECG, but has also had RBBB morphology in the past. He has extensive ectopy and is at risk for further rhythm disturbances.
4. Fever: The patient's fever is unclear, and potential etiologies include aspiration PNA, aspiration pneumonitis, or withdrawal. He is being monitored for signs of infection.
5. Liver function: The patient has elevated liver function tests, which may be related to shock liver or ischemic hepatitis. He is being monitored for signs of liver failure.
6. Hematuria: The patient had resolved hematuria, which was likely traumatic after Foley placement.
7. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his prolonged immobility and is being treated with SC heparin.
8. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to his critical illness and is being treated with ranitidine.
9. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to his intubation and is being treated with ranitidine per NGT and 30 degrees, mouth care.
10. Withdrawal: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and is at risk for withdrawal, particularly given his recent cessation of drinking.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and electrolytes.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function tests and blood counts.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and signs of infection.
4. Continue to manage the patient's pain and sedation.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust his fluids and vasopressors as necessary.
6. Consider a neurology consult to evaluate the patient's seizure risk.
7. Consider an EP consult to evaluate the patient's rhythm disturbances.
8. Consider a CT scan to evaluate the patient's potential stroke risk.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust his insulin therapy as necessary.
10. Consider a medication review to optimize the patient's medication regimen.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve. His cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has been diagnosed with anoxic brain injury. He is currently on a ventilator and has a tracheostomy tube in place. His heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia, and he has a dilated heart with preserved EF. He has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded to IV boluses of K+. He is being treated with vancomycin and levofloxacin for possible sepsis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's brain injury may lead to permanent cognitive impairment, seizures, or even death.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve increases his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which may worsen his condition.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated LFTs and cardiac enzymes suggest possible sepsis, which may lead to multi-organ failure.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's fevers and respiratory symptoms may indicate pneumonia, which may worsen his respiratory status.
5. Left to right shunt: The patient's aneurysmal interatrial septum may lead to a left to right shunt, which may worsen his cardiac function.
6. CAD: The patient's history of minimal CAD and mixomatous degeneration of the mitral valve may lead to further cardiac complications.
7. Cervical spine injury: The patient's cervical spine injury may lead to further complications, such as spinal cord injury or instability.
8. Neurological deficits: The patient's anoxic brain injury may lead to permanent neurological deficits, such as weakness, paralysis, or cognitive impairment.
9. Infection: The patient's sepsis and elevated LFTs suggest possible infection, which may lead to further complications.
10. Bleeding: The patient's history of possible cardiac arrest and anoxic brain injury may lead to bleeding complications, such as intracranial hemorrhage or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 64-year-old male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, was intubated and admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest. The patient's cardiac arrest was likely secondary to a primary arrhythmia, with the possibility of a stroke with atrial fibrillation. The patient's neurological status is still unclear due to his unresponsiveness.

The patient's CT head and neck scans showed signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, and a CT cervical spine scan revealed mild-to-moderate cervical spondylosis causing mild spinal canal stenosis.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated cardiac enzymes and liver function tests, consistent with cardiac injury and possible ischemic hepatitis. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but he has experienced episodes of ectopy and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, which have responded well to IV boluses of potassium.

The patient's medications include metoprolol, simvastatin, and aspirin, and he is being treated with vancomycin and levofloxacin for possible aspiration pneumonia. The patient's cardiac rhythm is currently sinus tachycardia, and he is being monitored for any changes in his cardiac status.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9°C (100.2°F), a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 116/73 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 99% and a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute.

The patient's neurological status remains unchanged, with no improvement in his responsiveness despite being off sedation for 48 hours. His pupils are 8mm and slightly reactive, and he has no withdrawal to pain or following commands.

The patient's physical examination reveals a soft and non-tender abdomen, with no masses or rebound/guarding. His skin is intact, with no rashes or lesions.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, creatine kinase, and lactate dehydrogenase, consistent with cardiac injury. His liver function tests are trending down, now close to normal.

The patient's medical history includes a history of alcohol abuse, but he is currently not showing signs of withdrawal.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and elevated cardiac enzymes suggest a high risk of recurrent arrhythmias.
2. Neurological deficits: The patient's unresponsiveness and lack of improvement in his neurological status suggest a high risk of permanent neurological deficits.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's history of aspiration and febrile response suggests a high risk of developing pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and febrile response suggest a high risk of developing sepsis.
5. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver function tests and history of ischemic hepatitis suggest a high risk of developing liver failure.
6. Kidney failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and history of cardiac arrest suggest a high risk of developing kidney failure.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his cardiac and neurological status closely and to adjust his medications and treatment plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after cardiac arrest and subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and liver function tests (LFTs). He has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve. The patient remains intubated and sedated, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 3. His cardiac arrest is still unclear, with possible etiologies including arrhythmia, stroke, and cardiac tamponade. He has signs of anoxic brain injury on CT scan, with no evidence of hemorrhage or shift.

The patient has been experiencing episodes of ectopy and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) despite being on metoprolol 75mg TID. His LFTs are trending down, and he has signs of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis. He has a cervical collar in place due to concerns about cervical spine instability.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Cardiac arrest: unclear etiology
2. Anoxic brain injury: confirmed on CT scan
3. Shock liver or ischemic hepatitis: confirmed on LFTs
4. Cervical spine instability: confirmed on CT scan
5. Mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve: confirmed on echocardiogram
6. Minimal CAD: confirmed on catheterization
7. Left to right shunt: possible secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac tamponade
2. Pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis due to aspiration
3. Sepsis or septic shock due to bacterial infection
4. Cervical spine instability or ligamentous injury
5. Anoxic brain injury or stroke
6. Shock liver or ischemic hepatitis
7. Cardiac failure or heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)
8. Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis
9. Respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
10. Neurological complications such as seizures, status epilepticus, or cerebral edema

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued cardiac monitoring and management of arrhythmias
2. Further investigation and treatment of anoxic brain injury
3. Management of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis
4. Cervical spine stabilization and monitoring
5. Antibiotics for possible pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis
6. Cardiac catheterization and possible percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
7. Pulmonary embolism prophylaxis and treatment
8. Respiratory support and management of respiratory failure
9. Neurological monitoring and management of neurological complications
10. Pain management and sedation as needed.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest, likely due to an arrhythmia. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His neurological status is unchanged, with no improvement in responsiveness despite being off sedation for 48 hours. A CT scan showed signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Anoxic Brain Injury:** The patient's anoxic brain injury is likely to result in significant cognitive and motor impairments. The extent of the injury is unclear, and further neuroimaging studies may be necessary to assess the damage.
2. **Cardiac Arrhythmias:** The patient's cardiac arrest was likely caused by an arrhythmia, and he continues to experience episodes of ectopy and NSVT. This may lead to further cardiac complications, such as ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia.
3. **Infection:** The patient's fever, which has been present for several days, may be due to aspiration pneumonia or pneumonitis. This could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. **Shock Liver:** The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, indicating possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis. This could lead to further liver damage and potential liver failure.
5. **Cervical Spine Injury:** Although the patient's CT scan did not show a fracture, there is still a possibility of ligamentous injury. If the patient awakens, further evaluation and management will be necessary to ensure proper alignment and stabilization of the cervical spine.
6. **Alcohol Withdrawal:** Although the patient does not appear to be experiencing withdrawal symptoms, he has a history of alcohol abuse and may be at risk for withdrawal if not managed properly.
7. **Pulmonary Embolism:** The patient's left-to-right shunt may increase his risk of pulmonary embolism, which could be life-threatening if not treated promptly.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation and pain management as necessary.
2. Perform further neuroimaging studies to assess the extent of the anoxic brain injury.
3. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac arrhythmias with medication and telemetry monitoring.
4. Treat the patient's fever with antibiotics and antipyretics, and consider further evaluation for possible infection.
5. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and manage shock liver or ischemic hepatitis with supportive care and potentially liver-directed therapies.
6. Continue to evaluate and manage the patient's cervical spine injury, and consider further imaging studies if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient for signs of alcohol withdrawal and provide appropriate treatment if necessary.
8. Consider further evaluation for pulmonary embolism, including echocardiography and ventilation-perfusion scanning.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, who was admitted after a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. The patient has been in the ICU for several days, and the following issues are currently being managed:

1. Neurological status: The patient remains unresponsive and has not shown any improvement in his neurological status despite being off sedation for 48 hours. A CT scan showed signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.
2. Cardiac status: The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has been diagnosed with shock liver or ischemic hepatitis. His heart rhythm is currently sinus rhythm, but he has had episodes of ectopy/NSVT in the past, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+.
3. Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever, which is being managed with tylenol. Sputum cultures have grown oral flora, and blood cultures are pending.
4. Left to right shunt: The patient has an aneurysmal interatrial septum without evidence of intracardiac shunting, which is likely causing the left to right shunt.
5. Cervical spine: A CT scan has ruled out fracture, but the patient's collar cannot be removed without an MRI or verbalization of pain.
6. Medications: The patient is receiving various medications, including vancomycin and levofloxacin for infection, metoprolol for heart rhythm control, and ASA for antiplatelet therapy.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count could indicate the development of sepsis.
2. Heart failure: The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, and he has a history of mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve, which could increase his risk of heart failure.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's fever and cough could indicate the development of pneumonia.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status has not improved despite being off sedation for 48 hours, and he has a history of seizure and cardiac arrest, which could increase his risk of neurological deterioration.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and history of bleeding could increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels could indicate kidney injury.
7. Liver injury: The patient's elevated liver enzymes could indicate liver injury.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status could deteriorate, especially if he develops pneumonia or sepsis.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory: The patient is on CPAP/PSV with a SpO2 of 93%. The ABG shows pH 7.50, PaCO2 33, PaO2 127, and HCO3 24. The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the underlying cause of the cardiac arrest is still unclear.
2. Neurological: The patient remains unresponsive and is off sedation for 48 hours. The CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. The patient exhibits muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements, which may be due to central neurological injuries. The neuro status has not improved, and further neurological recommendations are needed.
3. Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, and the cardiac arrest may have been caused by arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, or stroke with AFib. The patient's cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated. The patient is on telemetry monitoring, and further investigation and treatment are needed.
4. Infectious: The patient has a low-grade fever and is being treated with Vancomycin and Levofloxacin for a total of 7 days. The patient's blood cultures, sputum cultures, and CXR are pending.
5. Hematological: The patient's WBC count is 11.3, and the patient's Hct is 37.1.
6. Metabolic: The patient's glucose levels are within normal range, and the patient is being monitored for electrolyte imbalances.
7. Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and is being monitored for signs of withdrawal. The patient's liver function tests are trending down, indicating improvement.
8. Renal: The patient's creatinine levels are normal, and the patient is being monitored for signs of kidney dysfunction.
9. Musculoskeletal: The patient has a cervical collar in place due to the possibility of ligamentous injury, and the patient's neck should be cleared before the collar can be removed.
10. Skin: The patient has some skin breakdown and burn marks due to the defibrillator pads.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate, requiring more aggressive respiratory support.
2. Neurological decline: The patient's neurological status may worsen, leading to further injury or death.
3. Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient may experience further cardiac arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
4. Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis due to the presence of a fever and the possibility of a pulmonary infection.
5. Liver failure: The patient's liver function tests are trending down, but the patient may still be at risk for liver failure.
6. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are normal, but the patient may still be at risk for kidney dysfunction or failure.
7. Skin breakdown: The patient's skin breakdown may worsen, leading to further complications.

The patient's family meeting with the neurology and CCU team is scheduled for today, and the patient's wife will be present. The patient's code status is full code, and the patient is being transferred to the CCU for further care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Neurological status: The patient is unresponsive, but has shown some improvement in their neurological status over the past 24 hours. They have minor withdrawal to pain and more EEG activity, and are off sedation for 72 hours. The CT scan shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.
2. Cardiovascular status: The patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, and has had a possible seizure and cardiac arrest. They have been treated with Lasix and are being monitored on telemetry. The ECG shows a dilated heart with preserved EF, and there is evidence of mixomatous degeneration of the mitral valve.
3. Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on a ventilator, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 97%. They have coarse breath sounds throughout the lungs and are being treated with oxygen therapy.
4. Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 127/76 mmHg, and their heart rate is 77 beats per minute. They have a slightly elevated creatinine level, but their other laboratory values are within normal limits.
5. Infectious disease status: The patient has a fever, but it is not accompanied by leukocytosis. They have been treated with Levofloxacin for a total of 7 days, and their sputum cultures are negative for oral flora.
6. Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds, and their fiber intake is being repleted.
7. Other medical issues: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse, and is being monitored for signs of withdrawal. They have also been treated for shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, and their LFTs are trending down.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, as well as their possible seizure and cardiac arrest, make them at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and stroke.
2. Neurological complications: The patient's anoxic brain injury and possible stroke make them at risk for neurological complications such as seizures, brain edema, and long-term cognitive impairment.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's intubation and ventilation make them at risk for respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory failure, and respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Infectious disease complications: The patient's fever and treatment with antibiotics make them at risk for infectious disease complications such as sepsis, septic shock, and antibiotic-resistant infections.
5. Nutritional complications: The patient's tube feeds and repletion of fiber intake make them at risk for nutritional complications such as malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, and gastrointestinal complications.
6. Other medical complications: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and treatment for shock liver or ischemic hepatitis make them at risk for other medical complications such as liver failure, pancreatitis, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who was admitted to the ICU after possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He is currently unresponsive, on a ventilator, and has been off sedation for 72 hours. The patient has a CT scan showing signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift. His EEG suggests a moderate to severe encephalopathy involving cortical and subcortical structures, with posterior parasagittal suppression, which may warrant further investigation. The patient has a history of EtOH abuse, but no signs of withdrawal.

The patient has a cardiac arrest with unclear etiology, and further investigation is needed to determine the cause. He has been experiencing episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. His rhythm is dilated, with a preserved EF, and he has a history of possible Afib.

The patient has a left-to-right shunt, most likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, which is not possible to characterize with MRI due to intubation. He has a history of CAD, but catheterization showed minimal CAD. His LFTs are trending down, indicating shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.

The patient has a PICC line, which will be held for now, and he is receiving tube feeds. His glucose levels are being monitored, and he is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure: The patient's EEG suggests a moderate to severe encephalopathy, which may lead to seizures.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is unclear, and further investigation is needed to determine the cause.
3. Left-to-right shunt: The patient has a left-to-right shunt, which may lead to complications such as heart failure or pulmonary edema.
4. CAD: The patient has a history of CAD, which may lead to complications such as angina or myocardial infarction.
5. Shock liver: The patient's LFTs are trending down, indicating shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, which may lead to complications such as liver failure or bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and is at risk for infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is uncertain, and further investigation is needed to determine the extent of his brain injury.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely, and consider further investigation such as MRI or MRA to determine the extent of his brain injury.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and consider further investigation such as echocardiogram to determine the cause of his cardiac arrest.
3. Consider further investigation such as CT scan or MRI to determine the cause of his left-to-right shunt.
4. Monitor the patient's LFTs closely, and consider further investigation such as liver function tests to determine the extent of his shock liver.
5. Monitor the patient's glucose levels closely, and consider further investigation such as glucose tolerance test to determine the extent of his diabetes.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely, and consider further investigation such as electrolyte panel to determine the extent of his electrolyte imbalance.
7. Consider further investigation such as blood cultures to determine the cause of the patient's fever.

Based on the 24-hour events, the patient's condition remains critical with ongoing encephalopathy, fever, and cardiac rhythm disturbances. The patient's neurological status has shown minor improvement, but they remain unresponsive and require continued monitoring.

The patient's cardiac status is concerning, with episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded to IV boluses of K+. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a dilated heart with preserved EF, and the patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with ongoing mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy. The patient's abdominal exam is normal, and there are no signs of intra-abdominal pathology.

The patient's neurological exam is notable for 5mm pupils, reactive to light, and moderate responsiveness to stimuli. The patient has a history of possible seizure and cardiac arrest, and the EEG shows signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with elevated cardiac enzymes and LFTs, suggesting possible cardiac and liver injury. The patient's electrolytes are abnormal, with hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, which may contribute to their cardiac rhythm disturbances.

The patient's medical history is significant for MVP, bicuspid aortic valve, and possible alcohol abuse. The patient's family history is significant for a stapedectomy with a prosthetic stapes implant, which may be MRI-compatible, but the exact brand is unknown.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Deafness in the ear with the prosthetic stapes implant if the brand is incompatible with MRI.
2. Disruption of the oval window, which can cause a fluid leak and require surgical correction.
3. Cardiac rhythm disturbances, including arrhythmia and NSVT, which may require further investigation and treatment.
4. Encephalopathy, which may be related to the patient's underlying neurological condition or medication side effects.
5. Fever, which may be related to aspiration pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis.
6. Liver injury, which may be related to shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.
7. Cardiac failure, which may be related to the patient's underlying cardiac condition.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Ongoing mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Antibiotics for possible aspiration pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis.
3. Electrolyte repletion as needed.
4. Anti-seizure medication as needed.
5. Cardiac rhythm management, including IV boluses of K+ and increased metoprolol.
6. Monitoring of the patient's neurological status and possible MRI/MRA to further characterize the patient's condition.
7. Continued monitoring of the patient's cardiac status and possible cardiac MRI to further evaluate the patient's cardiac condition.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 64-year-old male who suffered a cardiac arrest, was intubated, and is currently minimally responsive.
* He has a history of MVP, bicuspid aortic valve, and possible seizure and cardiac arrest.
* His cardiac enzymes and LFTs are elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.
* He has an anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, and muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements are present.
* He has a fever, which may be due to aspiration PNA or pneumonitis, and his WBC count is elevated.
* He has dilated cardiomyopathy with preserved EF and mixed mitral valve disease.
* He has a possible left-to-right shunt, which may be secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return.
* He has no signs of heart failure at this time, but his EF is preserved.
* He has a cervical spine injury, which is being managed with a collar until further evaluation.
* He has a history of alcohol abuse, but no signs of withdrawal are currently present.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* Arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation (VFib) and atrial fibrillation (Afib)
	* Cardiac failure, given the patient's history of cardiac arrest and elevated cardiac enzymes
	* Increased ectopy/NSVT, which may require further management with K+ boluses and metoprolol
2. **Neurological Complications:**
	* Seizures, given the patient's history of possible seizure and cardiac arrest
	* Increased intracranial pressure, which may require further monitoring and management
	* Potential for further neurological deterioration, given the patient's anoxic brain injury
3. **Infectious Complications:**
	* Aspiration PNA or pneumonitis, which may require further antibiotic management
	* Possible sepsis, given the patient's elevated WBC count and fever
4. **Other Complications:**
	* Cervical spine instability, which may require further evaluation and management
	* Possible left-to-right shunt, which may require further evaluation and management
	* History of alcohol abuse, which may require further management and counseling

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and manage any arrhythmias that occur.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and manage any seizures or increased intracranial pressure.
3. Continue to manage the patient's fever and potential infections with antibiotics and other supportive measures.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cervical spine stability and manage any potential instability.
5. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's left-to-right shunt.
6. Continue to provide supportive care, including tube feeds, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who suffered cardiac arrest and is currently intubated and minimally responsive. The patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a preserved ejection fraction, and echocardiogram shows a dilated heart with aneurysmal interatrial septum without evidence of intracardiac shunting.
* Neurological: The patient is minimally responsive and has some eye blinking and posturing to sternal rub. He has 5mm pupils and is moderately responsive with equal bilateral pupillary response. There is no evidence of cranial nerve deficits.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and his urine output is -93 mL, which is below the goal of -500 mL.
* Hematological: The patient's white blood cell count is 11.3 K/uL, and his platelet count is 428 K/uL.
* Infectious: The patient has a fever of 100.2°F (37.9°C) and a WBC count of 11.3 K/uL. Sputum cultures are pending, and blood cultures have been sent.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded to IV boluses of K+. Further monitoring and management of electrolytes are necessary to prevent arrhythmias.
* Pneumonia: The patient has a fever and increased WBC count, which may indicate pneumonia. Sputum cultures and blood cultures are pending, and further antibiotics may be necessary if the patient develops pneumonia.
* Kidney injury: The patient's creatinine is elevated, and his urine output is below goal. Further monitoring of renal function and management of fluid balance are necessary to prevent further kidney injury.
* Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is uncertain, and further evaluation with MRI and CT scans is necessary to assess for potential neurological injuries.
* Left-to-right shunt: The patient has an aneurysmal interatrial septum, which may indicate a left-to-right shunt. Further evaluation with MRI and cardiac catheterization may be necessary to confirm this diagnosis.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and respiratory support as necessary.
* Monitor and manage cardiac arrhythmias with IV boluses of K+ and further management of electrolytes as necessary.
* Continue antibiotics for possible pneumonia, and further evaluate with sputum cultures and blood cultures.
* Monitor and manage renal function with further evaluation of creatinine and urine output.
* Continue to evaluate and manage neurological status with further evaluation with MRI and CT scans.
* Consider further evaluation with cardiac catheterization to confirm the diagnosis of left-to-right shunt.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological, and renal status to prevent further complications and optimize his outcome.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who suffered a cardiac arrest, intubated, and remains minimally responsive. The patient has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, and had a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.9°C (100.2°F), HR 78 bpm, BP 100/65 mmHg, RR 15 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%
* Neurological status: Off sedation, responding to sternal rub, not following commands, with 5mm pupils and moderate responsiveness
* Respiratory support: Intubated, ventilator mode MMV/PSV/AutoFlow, FiO2 40%
* Cardiovascular: Dilated heart in echocardiogram, preserved EF, bicuspid AS, and mixomatous degeneration of mitral valve
* Renal function: Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, BUN 25 mEq/L
* Liver function: LFTs trending down, close to normal
* Infection: Fever 100.2°F, WBC 11.3 K/uL, sputum culture showing oral flora
* Electrolytes: Potassium 4.9 mEq/L, magnesium 2.3 mg/dL, phosphorus 4.4 mg/dL
* Medications: Lasix 20mg IV x 2, Levofloxacin 500mg IV q 24h, Metoprolol 100mg po/ng TID, ASA 325mg daily, simvastatin 20mg po daily (stopped due to clean coronaries)

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk for recurrent arrhythmias, especially with the presence of dilated heart and preserved EF.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and increased WBC count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the presence of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis may increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
* Liver failure: The patient's LFTs are trending down, but the presence of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis may lead to liver failure.
* Pneumonia: The patient's fever and increased WBC count suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure.
* DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to immobility and the presence of a central line.
* Cervical spine injury: The patient has a cervical collar in place, and the presence of an aneurysmal interatrial septum may increase the risk of cervical spine injury.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Cardiac monitoring: The patient will continue to be monitored for cardiac arrhythmias and will receive IV boluses of K+ as needed.
* Antibiotic therapy: The patient will continue to receive Levofloxacin for a total of 7 days.
* Diuretic therapy: The patient will receive Lasix 40mg po BID to diurese.
* Neurological monitoring: The patient will continue to be monitored for neurological status and will receive further investigation and treatment as needed.
* Cervical spine management: The patient will continue to wear a cervical collar until the neck is cleared, and will receive MRI to assess the cervical spine.
* Infection control: The patient will receive VAP bundle and elevated head of bed to prevent aspiration pneumonia.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 64-year-old male who suffered a cardiac arrest, intubated, and remains minimally responsive.
* He has a history of MVP, bicuspid aortic valve, and possible seizure and cardiac arrest.
* He has slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.
* He is currently on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 15 inspirations per minute and a SpO2 of 96%.
* He has a fever of 100.2°F (38°C) and is being treated with tylenol.
* He has a dilated heart on echocardiogram with preserved EF, and is experiencing episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Arrest:** The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia at 220 BPM (VFib specifically), or stroke with AFib.
2. **Fever:** The patient's fever may be due to aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis, and his WBC count has increased to 11.3. He may require further investigation and treatment for this.
3. **Neurological Status:** The patient's neurological status is improving, but he remains minimally responsive. He has a possible PCA infarct on EEG and muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology.
4. **Left-to-Right Shunt:** The patient has a left-to-right shunt, likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, which may require further investigation with MRI.
5. **CAD:** The patient has minimal CAD, and his coronary arteries are clean.
6. **Cervical Spine:** The patient has a cervical spine collar in place, and will require MRI to clear the neck.
7. **Alcohol Abuse:** The patient has a history of alcohol abuse, and may require further management and treatment for this.
8. **Shock Liver or Ischemic Hepatitis:** The patient has LFTs that are trending down, indicating possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.
9. **VAP:** The patient is at risk for VAP due to his intubation and mechanical ventilation.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and respond to stimuli.
* Continue to manage his fever with tylenol and investigate possible causes.
* Continue to monitor his cardiac rhythm and treat any episodes of ectopy/NSVT.
* Consider further investigation with MRI to characterize the left-to-right shunt and cervical spine.
* Continue to manage his LFTs and consider further treatment for possible shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.
* Continue to monitor for signs of VAP and implement VAP bundle measures.
* Reassess the patient's cardiac status and consider further investigation with echocardiogram or stress test.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve s/p possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.

The patient has developed several medical complications, including:

1. Left upper extremity tremors of unclear etiology, which resolved with 1mg of ativan.
2. Fever, which has been afebrile in the last 24 hours, and is being monitored for potential aspiration pneumonia or pneumonitis.
3. Rhythm disturbances, including episodes of ectopy and NSVT, which have responded well to increased metoprolol.
4. Skin breakdown, including a stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of the cervical collar.
5. Respiratory failure, with a RSBI of 87, which may require weaning from the ventilator.
6. Left to right shunt, which is likely secondary to anomalous pulmonary venous return, and may require further characterization with MRI.
7. Shock liver or ischemic hepatitis, with LFTs trending down and close to normal.

The patient's medications include:

1. Lasix 20mg IV q12h for fluid management.
2. Metoprolol 100mg TID for rhythm control.
3. Levofloxacin for 7 days for antibiotic coverage.
4. Ranitidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
5. PAS for DVT prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs are:

1. Temperature: 37.2°C (99°F).
2. Heart rate: 78 bpm.
3. Blood pressure: 105/77 mmHg.
4. Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute.
5. Oxygen saturation: 95%.
6. Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is on a Swan-Ganz catheter.

The patient's laboratory results include:

1. WBC: 9.6 K/uL.
2. Hct: 36.3%.
3. Plt: 448 K/uL.
4. Cr: 0.9 mg/dL.
5. TropT: 0.02.
6. TCO2: 26.
7. Glucose: 127 mg/dL.
8. LFTs: Trending down and close to normal.

The patient's imaging studies include:

1. CT scan of the head with signs of anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift.
2. ECG with sinus rhythm.
3. TTE with aneurysmal interatrial septum without evidence of intracardiac shunting.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Monitoring of the left upper extremity tremors and potential EEG changes.
2. Further evaluation of the fever and potential aspiration pneumonia or pneumonitis.
3. Rhythm monitoring and management.
4. Skin breakdown management and pressure ulcer prevention.
5. Respiratory weaning and potential tracheostomy.
6. Left to right shunt evaluation and potential MRI.
7. LFT monitoring and management of shock liver or ischemic hepatitis.
8. ICU care and monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies.

The patient's disposition is CCU for now, pending further evaluation and management of his medical complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who suffered a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiovascular: The patient has a dilated heart with preserved EF, bicuspid AS, and mitral valve mixomatous degeneration. He has had episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to increased metoprolol.
* Neurological: The patient has an anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, and has shown minor withdrawal to pain and more EEG activity. He has left upper extremity tremors of unclear etiology.
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated on moderate settings, with an RSBI of 87. His lung status is appropriate for weaning, but given his depressed mental status, it will be held for now.
* Renal: The patient's urine output is 1,900 mL, and his creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a Stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of his cervical collar and is unable to assess his sacrum due to the collar.
* Skin: The patient has skin breakdown behind his neck where the collar was rubbing, and has slight burn marks where defibrillator pads were applied.
* Fever: The patient has a temperature of 37.2°C (99°F) and has been afebrile for the past 24 hours.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and further investigation is needed to determine the cause.
* Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is still uncertain, and further testing is needed to determine the extent of his brain injury.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still uncertain, and further testing is needed to determine the cause of his respiratory failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's urine output is 1,900 mL, and his creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL, which may indicate early signs of renal failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a Stage II pressure ulcer and is at risk for further gastrointestinal complications.
* Skin breakdown: The patient has skin breakdown behind his neck and is at risk for further skin breakdown.
* Infection: The patient has a fever and is at risk for infection.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring his cardiac status and treating any arrhythmias that occur.
* Monitoring his neurological status and treating any complications that arise.
* Monitoring his respiratory status and treating any complications that arise.
* Monitoring his renal function and treating any complications that arise.
* Monitoring his gastrointestinal status and treating any complications that arise.
* Monitoring his skin status and treating any complications that arise.
* Monitoring his temperature and treating any infections that arise.
* Ordering further testing, including an EEG, CT scan, and MRI, to determine the cause of the patient's cardiac arrest and neurological status.
* Treating any complications that arise, including cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, renal failure, gastrointestinal complications, and skin breakdown.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who was admitted with possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week. The patient has developed left upper extremity tremors, which are of unclear etiology. He has also shown improvement in his fever, with a decrease in WBC count.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, and etiologies suggest arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, or stroke with AFib. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause of the cardiac arrest.
2. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is improving, but he remains minimally responsive and intubated. He has developed muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements, which may be due to central neurological injuries. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of these symptoms.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated on moderate settings, and his lung status is appropriate for weaning. However, his depressed mental status may require continued intubation.
4. Left to Right Shunt: The patient has an anomalous pulmonary venous return, which may be causing a left to right shunt. Further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of this shunt.
5. Skin Breakdown: The patient has developed skin breakdown around his collar, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Fever: The patient's fever has improved, but further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his fever.
7. Rhythm Disturbances: The patient has experienced episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to IV boluses of K+. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of these rhythm disturbances.
8. Cardiac Enzyme Elevation: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, which may indicate cardiac damage. Further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of this damage.
9. Liver Function Tests: The patient's LFTs are trending down, but further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his liver dysfunction.
10. Cervical Spine Injury: The patient has a cervical spine injury, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and respond to any changes in his condition.
2. Further evaluate the patient's cardiac arrest and determine the cause of his cardiac enzymes.
3. Continue to manage the patient's fever and respiratory status.
4. Evaluate the patient's skin breakdown and determine the cause of his skin lesions.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's rhythm disturbances and respond to any changes in his cardiac rhythm.
6. Evaluate the patient's liver function tests and determine the cause of his liver dysfunction.
7. Further evaluate the patient's cervical spine injury and determine the cause of his skin breakdown.
8. Consider performing a cardiac MRI to further evaluate the patient's cardiac status.
9. Consider performing a brain MRI to further evaluate the patient's neurological status.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and respond to any changes in his electrolyte levels.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, who suffered a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.

The patient has a positive fluid balance, with an input of 2,084 mL and an output of 1,480 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 604 mL. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute and an SpO2 of 98%. His cardiac status is also stable, with a heart rate of 75 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 118/78 mmHg.

The patient has a number of medical complications, including:

1. Neurological status: The patient is minimally responsive and intubated, with a GCS score of 5T. He has a history of anoxic brain injury and is at risk for further neurological damage.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient suffered a cardiac arrest, which is still under investigation. He has a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve, which may have contributed to the arrest.
3. Fever: The patient has a temperature of 37.6°C, which is slightly elevated. He has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is at risk for further infection.
4. Skin breakdown: The patient has a stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of his cervical collar, which is at risk for further deterioration.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute. He is at risk for further respiratory failure.
6. Left to right shunt: The patient has a left to right shunt, which is likely secondary to an anomalous pulmonary venous return. This may require further evaluation and treatment.
7. CAD: The patient has a history of CAD, which is being managed with medication.

Potential medical complications:

1. Further neurological damage: The patient's neurological status is at risk for further deterioration due to his anoxic brain injury and the need for further evaluation and treatment.
2. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infection due to his fever and the need for further evaluation and treatment.
3. Skin breakdown: The patient's skin breakdown is at risk for further deterioration and may require further evaluation and treatment.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for further respiratory failure due to his intubation and the need for further evaluation and treatment.
5. Left to right shunt: The patient's left to right shunt may require further evaluation and treatment, which may carry risks.
6. CAD: The patient's CAD may require further evaluation and treatment, which may carry risks.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who was admitted with possible seizure and cardiac arrest. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week. The patient has a 3.5L positive fluid balance, and his input is greater than his output, with a goal of even to +300 cc today. He has a fever, which is being treated with antibiotics, and has a dilated heart with preserved EF on echocardiogram.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a cardiac arrest with unclear etiology, and is still at risk for further cardiac events.
2. Neurological injury: The patient has anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, and has left upper extremity tremors of unclear etiology.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated on moderate settings, and has a RSBI of 87.
4. Left to right shunt: The patient has an anomalous pulmonary venous return, which may be causing a left to right shunt.
5. Skin breakdown: The patient has a Stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of his cervical collar, and is at risk for further skin breakdown.
6. Fever: The patient has a fever, which is being treated with antibiotics, and is at risk for further infection.
7. Hypotension: The patient has a low blood pressure, which may be due to his cardiac arrest and neurological injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and antibiotics may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's intubation and respiratory failure may increase his risk of developing respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest and dilated heart may increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Skin infection: The patient's skin breakdown may increase his risk of developing a skin infection.
5. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological injury may worsen, leading to further neurological deterioration.
6. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac arrest and dilated heart may increase his risk of developing cardiac failure.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of MVP and bicuspid aortic valve who suffered a possible seizure and cardiac arrest with subsequent elevation in cardiac enzymes and LFTs. He remains minimally responsive and intubated, with slight improvement in his neurological status over the past week.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Cardiac arrest: The precipitant of the cardiac arrest is still unclear, but possible etiologies include arrhythmia, wide-complex tachycardia, and stroke with AFib.
* Neurological status: The patient has anoxic brain injury without hemorrhage or shift, with signs of muscle fasciculations and involuntary movements of unclear etiology. He has left upper extremity tremors of unknown etiology.
* Fever: The patient has a concern for aspiration PNA vs. aspiration pneumonitis, with decreased WBC count and afebrile in the last 24 hours.
* Rhythm: The patient has dilated heart in echocardiogram with preserved EF, bicuspid AS, and mitral valve mixomatous degeneration. He has episodes of ectopy/NSVT, which have responded well to increased metoprolol.
* Skin breakdown: The patient has a Stage II pressure ulcer around the edge of the cervical collar and is unable to remove it until a negative MRI is obtained.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated on moderate settings, with RSBI of 87. He is not ready for weaning due to his depressed mental status.
* Left to right shunt: The patient likely has an anomalous pulmonary venous return, which is not possible to characterize with intubation.
* CAD: The patient has minimal CAD, with clean coronaries and LDLc of 91.
* Pump: The patient has no signs of heart failure at this time, with preserved EF.
* Cervical spine: The patient has a CT scan without evidence of fracture, and is unable to remove the cervical collar until a negative MRI is obtained.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Neurological deterioration
* Pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis
* Skin breakdown and pressure ulcers
* Respiratory failure
* Left to right shunt and its complications
* CAD and its complications
* Heart failure
* Cervical spine injury or instability

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Monitoring of cardiac rhythm and electrolytes
* Administration of antibiotics for pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis
* Management of skin breakdown and pressure ulcers
* Weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Treatment of left to right shunt and its complications
* Management of CAD and its complications
* Monitoring of LFTs and glycemic control
* Nutrition and hydration support
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
